results.title: Strange events = Quelle strane occasioni
results.creator_credit: Rizzoli Film, Anonimo, Luigi Magni and Luigi Comencini
results.brief_description: This is a three-part tour de force featuring three of Italy’s best known comic actors coping with the trials and tribulations of love and sex. In the first story, Paolo Villagio plays an Italian immigrant who unwittingly becomes an entertainer in an Amsterdam porno parlour to make ends meet. The second story tells of a middle-aged man (Nino Manfredi) who is introduced to the permissive world of today’s youth by his teenage dughter and the daughter of an overnight visitor from Sweden. The third story features Roman comedian Alberto Sordi as a Monsignor and Stefania Sandrelli as a young lady who become accidentally locked in an elevator together on a warm mid-summer’s bank holiday. In Italian with no subtitles.

results.title: Strange days [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Lightstorm Entertainment, James Cameron, Steven-Charles Jaffe and Kathryn Bigelow
results.brief_description: Los Angeles. December 29, 1999 - the lead up to the new millennium. The city is close to anarchy, with crime and racial tensions creating an ever present sense of danger. Lenny Nero (Ralph Fiennes) is an ex-cop who now deals in illegal SQUIDS, CD-discs of memory/experiences used like a virtual reality game where the user gets to experience moments recorded from someone’s cerebral cortex. When Lenny’s friend Iris is murdered and he receives a SQUID clip of the incident, he stumbles into a web of killing and police corruption which involves his ex-girlfriend, rock singer Faith Justin (Juliette Lewis) and her gangster manager/lover Philo Gant (Michael Wincott). With help from friends Mace (Angela Bassett) and Max (Tom Sizemore), Lenny tries to find out who is behind the murders whilst not being killed himself. Written by James Cameron in collaboration with former film critic Jay Cocks, “Strange days” has strong performances from Ralph Fiennes and Angela Bassett who have a lot of fun with the role reversals - Lenny is a hopeless hero whilst Mace is the strong, heroic action heroine.

results.title: Strange Days (The Doors)
results.brief_description: “Strange Days” is a song by The Doors. It was released in 1967 and is the first track on the album of the same name. According to a review at AllMusic by Tom Maginnis, the song seems to find lead singer Jim Morrison “pondering the state of the then emerging hippie youth culture and how they are perceived by mainstream or ‘straight’ society”. A visit to New York City by The Doors inspired Jim Morrison to write “Strange Days” and other songs on Strange Days, the band’s second studio album. As with many other of their songs, it was written far before it was recorded; a live version recorded in May 1966 can be found on the album London Fog 1966.

results.title: Strange adventures of Mr. Smith
results.brief_description: Mr Smith (Gus McNaughton) leads a double life in order to maintain the elements of a middle-class security with his new wife (Eve Gray). However, his doubting mother-in-law embarks on a search for the truth which eventually is overtaken by various farcical situations involving Mr Smith and his alter ego. Cast includes Isobel Scaife, Michael Ripper, Bill Shine, Norma Varden, Aubrey Mallalieu.

results.title: Strand: under the dark cloth
results.creator_credit: John Walker Productions, Telefilm Canada and John Walker
results.brief_description: Documentary about modernist photographer Paul Strand (1890-1976), one of the seminal figures in the history of photography. Strand broke with the romantic pictorialist tradition to create a direct, dynamic photographic aesthetic. He was one of the first American artists to fully understand cubism, translating its vocabulary to the medium of photography. From 1914 onwards, Strand’s groundbreaking work encompassed abstract compositions, candid portraits, extreme close-ups of nature and documentation of social conditions. He was also a filmmaker and in 1921 he made America’s first avant-garde film, “Manhatta”, with painter Charles Sheeler. His growing political commitment, especially during and after the Great Depression, led him to embrace filmmaking as a means of political expression. In 1934 he became involved with a group of radical New York filmmakers, collaborating with Pare Lorentz on “The Plow that broke the plains” in 1936 and with Leo Hurwitz on “Native land”, a visually remarkable indictment of American civil rights abuses in 1941. The documentary contains interviews with Georgia O’Keefe, Milton Brown, Fred Zinnemann, Leo Hurwitz, Virginia Stevens, Hazel Strand, Cesare Zavattini, Blanche Brown and Walter Rosenblum. The titles “Native land” and “The plow that broke the plains” available on VHS.

results.title: Straight time
results.creator_credit: Sweetwall Productions, First Artists, Warner Bros Pictures, Stanley Beck, Tim Zinnemann and Ulu Grosbard
results.brief_description: Dustin Hoffman plays Max Dembo, a small time criminal paroled out of prison who desires to go straight. Initially Dembo’s main obstacle is his parole officer, Earl, who, aware of the power he wields, appears determined to ruin Dembo’s chance for a legitimate life. Living in a depressing half way house, Dembo attains a job in a factory and is soon dating a young woman unaccustomed to a man with Dembo’s past. Frustrated by the conditions of his parole, Dembo is drawn to old ties, and despite the fact that one friend has gone straight, is soon caught up in a web of petty crime. “Straight time” has a gritty urban feel that corresponds to the milieu of the era when American filmmakers were addressing issues of urban isolation, lack of personal freedom and the demise of the American ideals of free will and choice. Hoffman skilfully displays the frustrations of a man whose own incendiary personality coupled with ‘the system’, deny him any real chance at freedom. This was Hoffman’s second collaboration with director Ulu Grosbard, after “Who is Harry Kellerman and why is he saying those terrible things about me?”.

results.title: Straight talk on eye safety
results.brief_description: This film speaks directly to workers warning them of the tragic consequences that result from blinding accidents, and what such an accident will mean for their wives and children. Featuring Bill Frank who was blinded in a workshop accident.

results.title: Straight lines, pegs and satellites
results.creator_credit: Don Murray, Film Australia and Stanley Dalby
results.brief_description: Gives an overview of the varied work undertaken by surveyors, particularly the staff of the Australian Survey Office. Shows a range of work, from the measurement of dams, tunnels and towers to mapping of coastlines and reefs using the latest technology.

results.title: Straight line kinematics
results.brief_description: Everett M. Hafner demonstrates the relationships of distance, speed, acceleration and time using measuring equipment in a test car to illustrate the concepts. No other credits available.

results.title: Straight from the heart
results.creator_credit: Woman Vision (USA), Straight from the Heart, Dee Mosbacher and Frances Reid
results.brief_description: This program examines the issues parents face in coming to terms with a gay or lesbian child. It presents interviews with parents and children and tackles issues in a positive and thought provoking manner including the diagnosis of a child with HIV or AIDS. Academy Award Nominee, Documentary Short Subject Category, 1995.
